title: How to Boost Cell Phone Signal in Your Home

steps.headline: Determine your phone’s signal strength to see how weak it is.
steps.description: Dial a special number or check your settings to see the strength of your phone’s signal. If you have an iPhone, call international number #3001#12345# to activate your field testing services. If you have an Android, open your settings and scroll to signal strength section. Ideally, you’ll want your signal strength to be around -60dBm. If you have a measurement lower than -112dBM, then your phone has a very weak signal strength.

steps.headline: Put your phone in airplane mode for 3 seconds to reset the signal.
steps.description: Turn your phone’s cellular services off by activating airplane mode. This can be found in your phone’s settings, or in a quick access menu. Airplane mode helps to completely disconnect your phone from your carrier, which will reset your signal.

steps.headline: Enable WiFi calling on your phone to connect to a stronger signal.
steps.description: Go to your phone settings and activate WiFi calling, which allows you to make phone calls with your WiFi signal. If you have an iPhone, go to the “phone” portion of your settings to activate WiFi calling.If you have an Android phone, go to the “Advanced Calling” or “Networks” section of the settings to activate calling via WiFi. Make sure that your iPhone is completely up-to-date before toggling the WiFi calling option. Try searching through your settings on Android if you’re having difficulty finding the right section. Consider getting a portable WiFi hotspot if you don’t have WiFi at your house.

steps.headline: Choose a booster that works with your specific carrier.
steps.description: Make sure you get a product that works with all carriers, or works with the exact carrier of your phone. Some brands work with all cell phone carriers, but they can be on the pricier end, so it may be more cost-efficient to choose a signal booster that is specific to your carrier, depending  on your budget and cell phone plan. Regardless of the carrier, most signal booster products include a booster and an antenna.

steps.headline: Plug in the booster within the room that gets the most signal.
steps.description: Go to the room in your house that you use the most—in other words, the room that receives the most consistent coverage. The goal of a signal booster is to make your life more convenient, and it does this by being in an accessible location. Keep an eye on your signal bar as you walk through each room in your house. If you have an especially strong signal in one room, you might want to put the booster there. Check your device’s instructions to see how and where to plug in the booster.

steps.headline: Plug in the antenna near a window.
steps.description: Put the antenna portion close to a window so that it’s in a good position to receive a signal. While the booster works to increase your cell phone signal, it’s unable to do this until it has something to boost in the first place.

steps.headline: Make sure that both devices are turned on and operating.
steps.description: Check for a power button or switch to turn on the antenna and the booster. Although this goes without saying, double check to make sure that the power is turned on, and that electricity is reaching both devices. Once the signal booster is turned on, consider checking your phone’s signal strength. You can do this by downloading an app that lets you monitor your phone’s speed. Some good options are Speedtest by Ookla or Fast Speed Test by Netflix.

steps.headline: Research the coverage area of different networks and compare it to your current carrier.
steps.description: Go online and look up different coverage maps for various networks. Your current location might have weaker coverage than other places. Talk to your friends and family and see which cell phone carrier they have. This might help give you an idea of which networks are fastest in your area.

steps.headline: Compare the monthly rate of each network to your current plan.
steps.description: Check the websites of different cellular services and see what the monthly cost is for a plan. Before you make any commitments, confirm whether or not you want a contract or a prepaid plan. Make sure you have your phone’s IMEI number on hand if you do end up switching carriers. This number serves as your phone’s identity, and informs a new carrier of your phone’s hardware, along with other technical information. If you have an iPhone, you can find your IMEI by checking in the “General” and “About” sections of your settings. If you have an Android, you can get the number by from the “About Phone” and “Status” portions of your settings. You can find it on either type of phone by calling international number *#06#.

steps.headline: Opt for a plan with 4G LTE cellular service to improve your signal.
steps.description: Look into cell phone plans with fast connection speeds, like 4G LTE. This stands for Fourth Generation Long Term Evolution, and it works through progressive radio technology systems. If you don’t currently have 4G LTE, making the switch might boost your signal and increase your connection speed by a good margin. Several companies are working on 5G, or Fifth Generation technology. Ask a cell phone carrier representative when they think 5G services will be available in your area.

steps.headline: Talk to a sales representative before switching.
steps.description: Go to the store of a specific cell phone carrier or call ahead before switching your phone services completely. An in-person representative can answer any questions that you may have, and can explain all of your options to you. Go to ContactHelp.com or GetHuman.com if you’re having difficulties reaching an actual person.

text: Checking Your Phone’s Settings Determine your phone’s signal strength to see how weak it is. Dial a special number or check your settings to see the strength of your phone’s signal. If you have an iPhone, call international number #3001#12345# to activate your field testing services. If you have an Android, open your settings and scroll to signal strength section. Ideally, you’ll want your signal strength to be around -60dBm. If you have a measurement lower than -112dBM, then your phone has a very weak signal strength. Put your phone in airplane mode for 3 seconds to reset the signal. Turn your phone’s cellular services off by activating airplane mode. This can be found in your phone’s settings, or in a quick access menu. Airplane mode helps to completely disconnect your phone from your carrier, which will reset your signal. Enable WiFi calling on your phone to connect to a stronger signal. Go to your phone settings and activate WiFi calling, which allows you to make phone calls with your WiFi signal. If you have an iPhone, go to the “phone” portion of your settings to activate WiFi calling.If you have an Android phone, go to the “Advanced Calling” or “Networks” section of the settings to activate calling via WiFi. Make sure that your iPhone is completely up-to-date before toggling the WiFi calling option. Try searching through your settings on Android if you’re having difficulty finding the right section. Consider getting a portable WiFi hotspot if you don’t have WiFi at your house. Using a Signal Booster Choose a booster that works with your specific carrier. Regardless of the carrier, most signal booster products include a booster and an antenna. Plug in the booster within the room that gets the most signal. Go to the room in your house that you use the most—in other words, the room that receives the most consistent coverage. The goal of a signal booster is to make your life more convenient, and it does this by being in an accessible location. Keep an eye on your signal bar as you walk through each room in your house. If you have an especially strong signal in one room, you might want to put the booster there. Check your device’s instructions to see how and where to plug in the booster. Plug in the antenna near a window. Put the antenna portion close to a window so that it’s in a good position to receive a signal. While the booster works to increase your cell phone signal, it’s unable to do this until it has something to boost in the first place. Make sure that both devices are turned on and operating. Check for a power button or switch to turn on the antenna and the booster. Although this goes without saying, double check to make sure that the power is turned on, and that electricity is reaching both devices. Once the signal booster is turned on, consider checking your phone’s signal strength. You can do this by downloading an app that lets you monitor your phone’s speed. Some good options are Speedtest by Ookla or Fast Speed Test by Netflix. Switching Phone Carriers Research the coverage area of different networks and compare it to your current carrier. Talk to your friends and family and see which cell phone carrier they have. This might help give you an idea of which networks are fastest in your area. Compare the monthly rate of each network to your current plan. Check the websites of different cellular services and see what the monthly cost is for a plan. Before you make any commitments, confirm whether or not you want a contract or a prepaid plan. Make sure you have your phone’s IMEI number on hand if you do end up switching carriers. This number serves as your phone’s identity, and informs a new carrier of your phone’s hardware, along with other technical information. If you have an iPhone, you can find your IMEI by checking in the “General” and “About” sections of your settings. If you have an Android, you can get the number by from the “About Phone” and “Status” portions of your settings. You can find it on either type of phone by calling international number *#06#. Opt for a plan with 4G LTE cellular service to improve your signal. Look into cell phone plans with fast connection speeds, like 4G LTE. This stands for Fourth Generation Long Term Evolution, and it works through progressive radio technology systems. If you don’t currently have 4G LTE, making the switch might boost your signal and increase your connection speed by a good margin. Several companies are working on 5G, or Fifth Generation technology. Ask a cell phone carrier representative when they think 5G services will be available in your area. Talk to a sales representative before switching. Go to the store of a specific cell phone carrier or call ahead before switching your phone services completely. An in-person representative can answer any questions that you may have, and can explain all of your options to you. Go to ContactHelp.com or GetHuman.com if you’re having difficulties reaching an actual person.

If you have an Android, open your settings and scroll to signal strength section.
Ideally, you’ll want your signal strength to be around -60dBm.
If you have a measurement lower than -112dBM, then your phone has a very weak signal strength.
Put your phone in airplane mode for 3 seconds to reset the signal.
Turn your phone’s cellular services off by activating airplane mode.
This can be found in your phone’s settings, or in a quick access menu.
Airplane mode helps to completely disconnect your phone from your carrier, which will reset your signal.

Some brands work with all cell phone carriers, but they can be on the pricier end, so it may be more cost-efficient to choose a signal booster that is specific to your carrier, depending  on your budget and cell phone plan.
Regardless of the carrier, most signal booster products include a booster and an antenna.

While the booster works to increase your cell phone signal, it’s unable to do this until it has something to boost in the first place.

You can do this by downloading an app that lets you monitor your phone’s speed.

Switching Phone Carriers Research the coverage area of different networks and compare it to your current carrier.

Your current location might have weaker coverage than other places.

This might help give you an idea of which networks are fastest in your area.

Check the websites of different cellular services and see what the monthly cost is for a plan.

If you have an Android, you can get the number by from the “About Phone” and “Status” portions of your settings.
You can find it on either type of phone by calling international number *#06#.
Opt for a plan with 4G LTE cellular service to improve your signal.
